cause:
Analysis:The problem occurred due to failure to meet the minimum aging time of the parts (48 hours) prior to shipment. This occurred because the production plan did not meet the adequate cooling time and there was no advance inspection based on Kanban. In addition, the parts were not available with the required aging time in stock, which resulted in moisture in the parts during the shipping process.

Root Cause: The root cause was the shipment of the parts without respecting the minimum inventory time of 48 hours, which is necessary to ensure adequate cooling of the parts prior to delivery.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The short term solution included performing an advance inspection of the items based on the Kanban of the upcoming deliveries and recording the shipment inspections, noting the date of manufacture and batch of the parts. These actions were implemented to ensure that the parts met the aging requirements prior to shipment.


Long Term Solution:  The long term solution involves implementing a continuous inspection system using Kanban to monitor curing time and ensure that all parts are inspected based on the appropriate cooling time. In addition, measures such as ventilation on the benches to cool the parts and removing excess moisture from the parts post-molding were taken to prevent similar issues in the future.

cause:
Analysis: The analysis reveals that moisture condensed on the parts due to a failure in the steam distribution system. The steam accumulator generated excess water, which was not properly removed, causing condensation on the parts. In addition, the LQC inspection did not detect internal moisture due to a superficial assessment, and the OQC inspector did not properly assess the parts, which resulted in the moisture being identified only after the parts were shipped to the customer.
Root Cause: The root cause of the problem was the failure to remove the moisture generated by the steam condensation. The lack of efficient containment for the condensate and the failure of the steam distribution system (steam accumulator) resulted in the excess moisture. In addition, the failure to inspect during the quality control process (LQC and OQC) prevented early detection of the problem.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The short term solution was the installation of a gutter to divert the condensed steam from the parts. This would help reduce the amount of moisture that would come into contact with the parts, minimizing the problem immediately.


Long Term Solution:The long term solution includes improving the method of moisture detection in the OQC area, ensuring that inspections are more effective and can detect internal moisture in the parts. This involves re-evaluating and possibly revising the quality control processes, as well as taking steps to improve the moisture removal system in the molding process.

cause:
Analysis: The analysis reveals that the problem is related to variations in the cutting and creasing of the sheet, with errors in the measurement of the tabs, variation in the cutting unit, and inconsistencies in the tooling. The cutting of the bottom tabs is out of specification, especially in projects with tabs greater than 120mm, in addition to failures in inspection and inadequate work instructions.
Root Cause: The root cause identified was the variation in the cutting of the sheet in the cutting and creasing unit, resulting in incorrect dimensional tabs. Failure to measure the gap between tabs and the lack of clarity in the work instructions also contributed to the problem.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The short term solution includes immediate adjustment in the tooling, such as increasing the rotary mold by 2mm to minimize the variation in the bottom tabs of the specific model M44GJA746150100KM and implementing a production monitoring with the improvement applied.


Long Term Solution:The long term solution involves creating LUPs (List of Operating Procedures) and training on inspection of tabs over 120mm, updating rotary molds and drawings, and mapping all die cut items with tabs over 120mm for ongoing and comprehensive adjustments.

cause:
Analysis: The problem occurred due to excessive pressure on the printer's input roller, which was caused by the illegibility of the pressure indicator. The indicator gradually faded during the machine's cleaning, and due to its illegibility, the operator did not notice the change in pressure, which led to process failures such as over-glued plates and warped plates.
Root Cause: 
The root cause was the loss of legibility of the pressure indicator during the machine's cleaning process, which prevented the operator from detecting the correct pressure and led to failures in the production process.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The short-term solution was to request maintenance to replace the pressure indicator, with a deadline of 01/31/2025, to ensure that the indicator is legible and works correctly, avoiding immediate operational failures.


Long Term Solution:The long-term solution was to include checking the legibility conditions of the pressure indicator in the routine verification checklist, with a deadline of 02/03/2025, to ensure that this problem does not recur and that the operator can always monitor the pressure correctly during the process.

correctiveActions:

Long Term Solution:The long term solution is to develop and adopt labels with a stronger adhesive that is suitable to withstand the product's use conditions. This includes conducting regular environmental testing and increasing product inspection sampling to ensure that the label remains properly attached throughout its useful life.

cause:
Analysis: The analysis reveals that the problem occurred due to operational failures in the paint change process. During the operation, there was no measurement of the paint viscosity and no verification of the appropriate color standard before starting the production process. In addition, the paint mixture with water was not adequately consolidated, which generated inconsistencies in production. These failures were not detected in time, which led to problems in the process.
Root Cause: 
The root cause of the problem was the lack of adequate verification and control of the viscosity and color standard. Specifically:
The operator did not measure the paint viscosity before starting the production process.
The color standard was outside the desired parameters, but was adjusted without proper verification before production.
There was also a lack of procedure to wait for the paint to return to the bucket to ensure adequate mixing with the water.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The short-term solution includes immediate guidance to the team of operators on the importance of measuring the paint viscosity and verifying the color standard before starting the production process. In addition, the technical instructions (TI) will include the requirement to perform these checks before diluting the paint. This must be implemented by 02/03/2025 (for viscosity) and 02/05/2025 (for TI).


Long Term Solution:The long-term solution involves permanent changes to the technical instructions (TI), establishing clear and mandatory procedures for measuring viscosity and checking the color standard before starting any production process. An ongoing training and awareness process will also be implemented to ensure that all operators are aware of good practices and the importance of following these procedures. These actions will be monitored to ensure that the problem does not recur.

cause:
Analysis:The problem of the cover peeling off on Wave B occurred due to insufficient heat in the paper, caused by an inadequate temperature in the press roller. The failure was caused by the condensate return valve that was closed after adjustments, which prevented the proper release of condensate and affected the temperature required for the pressing process. 
Root Cause:The root cause was that the condensate return valve was closed to make an adjustment, but was not reopened after the activity was completed, resulting in an inadequate temperature in the press roller, which compromised the quality of the pressing process and caused the cover to peel off.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution:The material was segregated and returned to the supplier. 
As an immediate solution, the condensate release valve was adjusted, ensuring that the pressing process had the appropriate temperature. In addition, the calibration of the press roller was included in the temperature checklist, with a deadline of 01/28/2025.


Long Term Solution:To prevent recurrences, a one-point lesson will be created to guide the team to check whether the valve is open or closed before finalizing any adjustments. This action is intended to ensure that the valve is not forgotten, with a deadline for implementation until 02/10/2025.

cause:
Analysis: The problem identified was partial application of glue to the lap, caused by sensor reading errors, glue valve jamming, and lack of proper maintenance of the glue application system. The failure was difficult to detect initially due to sensor oscillation and the reviewer's lack of awareness in identifying the glue application failure. The problem occurs randomly, which made early detection difficult.
Root Cause: The failure occurred because the vest sensor failed to read the lap size, which directly impacted the glue application.

The glue valve was jammed due to crystallized glue that was not removed through proper maintenance.

The operation did not perform regular cleaning of the glue application system, which led to the accumulation of dried glue in the system.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The material was segregated and reworked
A work order was opened to correct the problem immediately and ensure proper glue application.

The gluing teams met to report the problem and the necessary adjustments to the process.

The failure was addressed urgently to avoid further impacts on production.


Long Term Solution: Implementation of regular maintenance, including completing the vest cleaning checklist, with biweekly washing of the glue application system to prevent the accumulation of dried glue.

Improvement in the monitoring and calibration of the lap size sensor to avoid reading errors.

Implementation of continuous checking of the glue valves to ensure they are functioning properly.

Additional training of the overhaul team to ensure that failures such as partial glue application are identified immediately.

These actions aim not only to correct the problem immediately, but also to prevent its recurrence in the future.

cause:
Analysis: The analysis identified that the variation in component fit during the SMT process was the main cause of the problem. This variation in fit led to the component not being sucked into the nozzle, compromising correct assembly. The analysis also revealed that the final test was not adequately covering critical components, such as connectors, which made it difficult to detect the problem. In addition, the AOI was positioned before the machine that assembled the connector, which prevented the defect from being detected during visual inspection.

Root Cause: The root cause of the problem was the variation in component fit during the SMT process, which occurred due to inadequate adjustments in the SMT program and in the centering of the pickup point. The failure to detect this problem in the final process was also attributed to the test method used, which did not cover all critical components, such as connectors.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The short term solution involved implementing immediate actions such as:

Reinforced QA training on the SMT and FA production lines to ensure that component fit and assembly were performed correctly.

Adjustment of the SMT program to ensure that component recognition was adequate, adjusting the recognition range and component height.

Training operators to identify problems in the final process using jigs, ensuring that fit failures were detected.

Adjustment of pickup for large components with feeders above 12mm, in order to avoid variations in pickup position after splicing.

Long Term Solution: The long term solution focused on implementing permanent adjustments and process improvements to prevent the problem from recurring:

Continuous training of QA and operators to maintain constant attention to critical points in the SMT and FA process.
Adjustments to the SMT program and pickup process to ensure accurate recognition and proper centering of the pickup point.
Improved final testing to properly cover connectors and other critical components, ensuring no failures are missed during inspection.
Implemented pickup adjustments on all large components with feeders above 12mm to reduce process variations and failures.

cause:
Analysis:The analysis of the problem revealed that the false crease occurred during the handling of the packages in the gluing machine. The review process was being carried out by only one person, and the small boxes contributed to the appearance of the defect. In addition, the way the packages were placed on the pallet also influenced the problem, making it difficult to detect faults during handling. This fault was not identified in time, which generated the defect in the boxes.

Root Cause: The root cause of the problem was the handling of the packages by only one person in the gluing process, combined with the fault in the method used to review the boxes, especially the small ones, which favored the formation of the false crease.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution:The short-term solution includes:

Review the Work Instruction (WI) to improve the package handling process, with a deadline of February 26, 2024, under the responsibility of José Pires.

Change handling to be performed by two people, ensuring a more effective review and reducing the risk of false creasing.

Inform and train teams on the new handling and review method, also with a deadline of 02/26/2024.


Long Term Solution:
The long-term solution consists of:

Permanent review of the Work Instruction (WI), so that handling of boxes is performed by two employees, as a standard procedure, with a deadline for implementation of 02/26/2025.

Continuous training of teams, to ensure that the new method is followed correctly and that the review of the gluing process is effective, with a deadline of 02/26/2025.

Monitoring and evaluation of the process, to ensure that false creasing does not occur in other TV models and that the efficiency of the new method is maintained.

cause:
Analysis:
The problem occurred due to excess glue caused by the abnormal glue application valve, specifically the accumulation of crystallized glue in the valve. This accumulation was facilitated by the lack of cleaning of the valve, which did not follow an adequate schedule. In addition, the difficulty in using the valve and the fact that the glue was still curing after leaving the gluer made it difficult to detect the problem. The problem occurred randomly, which made it more difficult to identify.

Root Cause: The root cause of the problem was the lack of a valve cleaning schedule, which led to the accumulation of crystallized glue and made it difficult to use the application valve properly. In addition, the lack of a regular maintenance process, such as scheduled cleaning every 10 days, directly contributed to the problem. 3 - Short Term Solution:
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution:Requesting that valve cleaning be included in the maintenance schedule to ensure that the valve is cleaned regularly and with a deadline of 03/25/2025, under the responsibility of José Pires.

Including valve cleaning every 10 days in the production checklist to ensure that this process is followed, with a deadline of 03/25/2025, under the responsibility of José Pires.

Training with process employees to reinforce the importance of correct and regular cleaning of the valve, with a deadline of 03/25/2025, under the responsibility of José Pires.


Long Term Solution:Implementing an ongoing maintenance schedule to ensure that the valve is cleaned regularly and that the problem of glue build-up is avoided in the future.

Continuous verification of the production checklist to ensure that valve cleaning is performed every 10 days, as per the new established procedure.

Continuous monitoring of the effectiveness of the maintenance schedule and staff training, to ensure that corrective actions are sustainable and applicable to other products and processes.

cause:
Analysis:The analysis reveals that the problem occurred due to flaws in the proofreading process and material handling. Specifically:

The ink roller was improperly loaded, resulting in broken screws.
The roller went out of parallel, which led to a printing and barcode issue.
The proofreading failure was caused by an inadequate method, in which only one person was responsible for proofreading. This prevented errors from being detected, such as the incorrect placement of the barcode, which was at the bottom of the box and could not be properly viewed.

Root Cause: The root cause identified was the out-of-parallel rubber roller, which caused printing and barcode alignment failures. This, in turn, resulted in flaws in the proofreading process and error detection. In addition, the flawed proofreading method (with only one person doing the proofreading) and the machine structure (which only supports one proofreader) contributed to the detection failure.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The short term solution consists of:

Opening a work order to replace the broken screws on the ink roller, avoiding further mechanical failures.
Implementing a rework to correct the placement of the barcodes on the boxes, with two options:
Sending the boxes to ENVISION + PCE personnel to apply the labels.
ENVISION sends the labels to PCE so that the rework can be done there.
Revising the work instructions for the stitchers to improve the printing verification.


Long Term Solution:The long term solution involves:

Adjusting the machine structure to allow more than one person to perform the review, decreasing the burden on the single reviewer and increasing the efficiency of the process.
Revising the OQC/LQC report to ensure that the barcode is properly verified with a reader, which would avoid reading and placement errors.
Revising and improving the review and training methods in order to minimize the chance of similar failures in the future.

cause:
Analysis: 
The problem occurred during the stoppage to clean the clichés, when the assistants forgot to press the "AUTO ZERO" button after cleaning. This button is essential to ensure that the printing returns to the original register. The operational failure was not detected at the time, which led to the printing being out of register. When the process was restarted, the problem was identified, but the defective boxes were not removed from the line, and the defective table was sent to the gluing machine without proper identification for review.

Root Cause: The root cause of the problem was a failure in the operational method during the machine stoppage, specifically the failure to press the "AUTO ZERO" button after cleaning the clichés. In addition, there was no adequate procedure in the Quality Control checklist to identify tables originating from machine stoppages, which contributed to the failure not being detected in time. 3 - Short Term Solution:
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Meeting the production team to inform them about the problem that occurred and reinforcing the importance of pressing the "AUTO ZERO" button after machine downtime, with a deadline of 03/11/2025, under the responsibility of José Pires.

Instructing assistants to remove defective boxes during the correction process and ensuring that tables originating from machine downtime are identified and reviewed 100%.

Reviewing the Quality Control inspection report, including a new guideline that identifies and reviews 100% of tables originating from machine downtime, with a deadline of 03/11/2025, under the responsibility of Ayrton.

Long Term Solution: The long-term solution includes:

Continuous review of the machine shutdown method, ensuring that all operators always press the "AUTO ZERO" button after cleaning, with ongoing training to reinforce this procedure.

Adjustment to the Quality Control checklist to ensure that tables resulting from machine shutdowns are always identified and 100% reviewed, with a deadline of March 11, 2025.

Process monitoring to ensure that the changes implemented are followed and that similar problems are avoided in other production models.

cause:
Analysis: The problem identified was the failure to glue the lap of the boxes, resulting in rework. The analysis of the "Whys" showed that the glue did not penetrate the paper properly due to the presence of ink on the lap and the use of an inadequate puller ("flat" type), which is not ideal for this type of application. In addition, the deviation was not detected during the inspection, as only a visual analysis was performed, without frequent destructive tests during production.

Root Cause: The root cause is the use of the "flat" type puller, which covers the lap with ink and prevents the glue from adhering properly to the paper, aggravated by the lack of standardization in the type of puller used for heavy composition items.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution:The short-term solutions implemented were:
Checking the application of the dashed type puller.
Checking the existence and use of the LUP (Pull Usage List).
Increased lap and standardized application of three glue threads to improve adhesion on items such as the BC Wave Die Cut.
Long Term Solution: Long-term solutions include:

Permanent replacement of the "solid" type handle with the "traced" type.

Creation and standardization of LUPs to ensure that only suitable handles are used in similar processes.

Review of the inspection process, including the implementation of destructive tests during production and operator training to ensure early detection of failures.

cause:
Analysis: It was identified that the remote control was not working due to the absence of a pulse on the LED, caused by a lack of electrical continuity in resistor R1. Analysis using an electron microscope revealed a structural rupture in the resistor on its contact surface with the board, where the intermetallic weld is formed. The failure, although with a low incidence (5 PPM), was not detected during the inspection because there was an error in the testing and registration process: the operator got confused and approved a defective part, aggravated by the fact that the approval control was manual and without physical barriers.

Root Cause: Structural failure in resistor R1 (1R0), which compromised electrical continuity, combined with a human error in the inspection and registration process — the operator incorrectly approved the defective part, and the system allowed this error due to the lack of robust control.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution:Monitoring of recurrence of the defect and continuous analysis based on new evidence.
Responsible: Paulo Caresto – Deadline: 04/06/2025
Inclusion of ohmic measurement of the soldered resistor in sample inspections (CQ-IA).
Responsible: Paulo Ferreira – Deadline: 06/06/2025
Reduction of the rework rate (touch-up) to minimize soldering failures.
Responsible: Kleber S. – Deadline: 04/06/2025
Long Term Solution: Implementation of a physical barrier to prevent remote controls from going through the process without testing.
Responsible: Klinger C. – Deadline: 30/05/2025

Changing the registration logic in the approval system:
Only OK parts will be registered by the operator.
NG parts will be registered separately by a technician at another station.
Responsible: Núbia L. – Deadline: 05/30/2025
Reinforcement of structural inspection of resistors with ohmic measurement and welding analysis.

technicalAnalysis:
16/07/2025 - it was performed critical analysis and we have asked for the supplier to revise the actions plan
Due date: 17/07/2025
cause:
Analysis:During the gluing process, it was determined that the sheets were being glued incorrectly. The analysis revealed that the upper gluing limiter sensor was partially obstructed, causing it to close beyond the ideal point. Furthermore, there was no preventive inspection or adequate checklist to verify the sensor's condition before production. The overlapping sheets contributed to the difficulty in immediately detecting the failure.
Root Cause: The root cause was the partial obstruction of the upper gluing limiter sensor, which caused the gluing limiter to lose its reference and close beyond the required point. This was due to the lack of preventive inspection and cleaning, combined with a lack of standardized machine checklists.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Immediate cleaning of the upper gluing limiter sensor.
Repositioning and testing of the sensor after cleaning to ensure proper operation.
These actions were completed by June 30, 2025.
Long Term Solution: Inclusion of sensor verification in the machine startup checklist.
Strengthening the gluing machine checklist, ensuring visual inspections.
Team training on the symptoms and solutions for identified deviations.
Establishing a preventive and periodic cleaning routine for the sensor.
All these actions are scheduled for completion between July 2, 2025, and July 20, 2025.

technicalAnalysis: 21/08/2025 - e-mail sent to the supplier asking for the 8D analysis
cause:
Analysis: The analysis showed that these spots are not process defects, but rather natural characteristics of virgin kraft paper, resulting from the presence of fibers and impurities from the wood used in papermaking.

The initial focus of the project was on strength and sustainability, not the aesthetics of the material, and there was no visual specification defining acceptance limits for this type of appearance.

Root Cause: The base material (virgin kraft paper) contains natural dark particles resulting from the manufacturing process.
The supplier, Georgia Pacific, confirmed that these specks are inherent to the production process and do not compromise the functional quality of the paper.
Therefore, the root cause is a natural characteristic of the material used, not a manufacturing defect.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Segregation of affected materials (in stock and production) until the customer's decision.

Temporarily blocking boxes with black spots to prevent incorrect shipments.

Meeting with the customer (Envision) to clarify the origin and nature of the problem, seeking provisional approval for the use of the material.


Long Term Solution: Reinforce the visual criteria for accepting kraft paper with the customer, avoiding subjective interpretations.

Inform the supplier, Georgia Pacific, of the opportunity to improve visual control of the paper.

Adjust the internal process (corrugator): use rolls with visible spots only on the inside cover, maintaining the aesthetics of the outside.

Train the quality and production team to visually identify materials with dark spots and dispose of them appropriately.

Investigation revealed that a swollen shim (calço inchado) and a broken support clip (grapa) led to misalignment of the mold halves, allowing unintended opening during the molding process. The issue was not detected in time because the dimensional variation occurred after quality release and was not caught during visual or dimensional inspection.

Root Cause: Failure in the fixation of the mold’s support clips (grapas) caused misalignment between the fixed and moving parts of the mold, resulting in improper sealing and out-of-spec parts.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Evaluate the current setup method focusing on mold fixation – Tony Ferreira (25/07/2025)
Update the work instruction (IPC-01.10) to include proper fixation methods to prevent warping – Tony Ferreira (31/07/2025)
Long Term Solution: Develop a go/no-go gauge to check shim height (45 mm and 65 mm) – Tony Ferreira (25/07/2025)
Implement a control routine for support clips (grapas) in all setup operations – Tony Ferreira (25/07/2025)
Ongoing monitoring to ensure dimensional stability during production

Symptom: Back cover missing guide injected
technicalAnalysis: 21/08/2025- Follow up with the supplier for asking action plan evidences
cause:
Analysis: During the injection molding process, a part was produced without a lower fitting. The investigation showed that the failure occurred because the fitting area broken and became stuck in the mold cavity, caused by a machine restart after a shutdown with degraded material and a lack of inspection. Furthermore, there was no checkpoint for the fitting in quality control, and the guide pin was not classified as a critical dimension in the product drawing.

Root Cause: Failure in the machine restart procedure after stopping, without purging the degraded material in the cylinder, resulting in the lower fitting breaking and being retained in the mold.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Perform a full inspection of the material before starting production. Inspect parts produced after restarting to identify and remove any defects. Instruct operators on visually inspecting the lower fitting.


Long Term Solution: To develop and implement a formal procedure for machine restart (with mandatory purge).Train operators in the new procedure. Include the fitting/dowel pin as a checkpoint in the quality setup and PIC.
Update drawings to identify the dowel pin as a critical dimension.

cause:
Analysis: Upon receipt of the 32LR600BPSA LG packages, a false crease was identified, caused by excessive pressure on the boxes located on the lower layers of the pallets.
Analysis revealed that the pallets were stacked on top of each other due to a lack of physical space in the shipping area. The problem was not detected during shipment because the packages were wrapped in stretch film, making a complete visual inspection impossible.

Root Cause:  Lack of adequate physical space in the shipping area, which led to improper stacking of pallets containing pressure-sensitive packaging during periods of high production volume.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Separation and return of non-compliant material to the supplier (immediate containment action).
Furthermore, the stacking of pallets containing sensitive packaging was suspended until the area was definitively reorganized.

Long Term Solution: Redesigning the shipping layout, creating dedicated areas for storing sensitive materials and avoiding stacking.

Training and raising awareness among operational staff about the risks of improper stacking and reinforcing proper handling practices.

description:
Where: Line T04
Description: Carton Box
Invoice: 000387578-1
Qty: 400
Part number: M44GK54281303B0PHX
Defect Rate (FOR): 125/400 = 31,3% %  312.500/ PPM
Rate: 31,3%
Symptom: Wrong Layout
cause:
Analysis: It was discovered that all model 24M2N3200L packages had an incorrect date stamp position, which was applied to the wrong panel of the printing plate.
The error occurred because, after replacing the date stamp during production, the production assistant repositioned it without a clear reference, as the Printing Form (FI) did not indicate the correct location for traceability.

Root Cause: The Printing Form (FI) did not have the mandatory indication of the correct location for applying the date stamp, allowing incorrect interpretation by the operator during the printing process.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The material was released with conditional approval (Waiver) after review, as the error did not compromise the packaging's functionality.
The production team was also instructed on the correct positioning of the dater until the FIs were formally updated.

Long Term Solution: Incluir no processo da Clicheria a obrigatoriedade de indicar claramente o local de aplicação do datador nas Fichas de Impressão (FI).

Treinar a equipe de produção e impressão para conferir o posicionamento do datador sempre que houver troca ou ajuste de setup.

description:
Where: Line T03
Description: Carton Box
Invoice: 000388951-1
Qty: 1.600
Part number: M44GJC9368903A
Defect Rate (FOR): 190/1600 = 11,9% %  118.750 PPM
Rate: 11,9%
Symptom: Boxes with stain
cause:
Analysis: The analysis showed that these stains arise during the corrugation process and are considered inherent characteristics of the Kraft paper manufacturing process.
Previously, there was no visual acceptance standard or guideline to classify this type of variation as a defect.
Visual inspection also lacked specific criteria for rejecting these stains, as they were considered normal and had no functional impact.

Root Cause: The white spots were accepted as normal characteristics of the material because they did not affect the strength or functionality of the packaging, and there was no visual pattern or history of aesthetic impact.
The paper supplier (Georgia Pacific) considers these spots inherent to the manufacturing process and does not recognize them as a quality defect.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The material was reviewed by the supplier and returned to PCE for rework and segregation of the affected packaging.
Only boxes that met acceptable visual standards were released for use.

Long Term Solution: Implementation of a visual filter during the finishing process, separating packaging with stains in critical areas (logo, text, identification information).

Train the operational team on the new visual acceptance criteria and definition of "critical areas."

Determine that rolls with visible stains will not be used on the outer cover of the boxes, but only on the inner cover.

Confirm with the client (Envision) that the white stains are a characteristic of the process and do not represent a functional or structural failure.

description:
Where: Line T01
Description: Carton Box
Invoice: 000389132-1
Qty: 410
Part number: M211500GFU10SFLP0A
Defect Rate (FOR): 32/410 = 0,08 % %  78.049 PPM
Rate: 0,08 %
Symptom: Rigid Top Flaps
technicalAnalysis: 03/11/2025 - E-mails sent to the supplier asking for the 8D analysis
cause:
Analysis: The problem occurred because the paper weight was at the upper limit of the specification, making the sheets more rigid than expected. The combination of this rigidity with the box design (crease and flaps) made it difficult to close at the customer's location. The inspection did not detect the defect because quality control only evaluated dimensional and physical parameters, without functional analysis of flexibility or closing force.

Root Cause: The variation in the coil's basis weight, although within specifications, was concentrated at the upper limit, increasing the sheet's rigidity and compromising the box's performance in the customer's operation.
This variation was not detected because the inspection process does not include functional criteria (flexibility/closure).
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The PCE  team reworked the material, separating and adjusting the rigid boxes to allow for customer use.

Long Term Solution: Training and guidance for operators of the Corrugating Machine, Printing Machine, and Quality Control to identify noticeable variations in stiffness or thickness during production and to immediately report them to management.

description:
Where: Line T04
Description: Carton Box
Invoice: 000389457-1
Qty:2.000
Part number: M44GB93160803E04G1
Defect Rate (FOR): 25/2.000 = 1.3% 12.500PPM
Rate: 1.3%
Symptom:Rupture in the top flaps
cause:
Analysis: During the incoming inspection of S22e-18 packaging, it was found that some of the boxes had poor adhesion between the layers of corrugated cardboard, resulting in delamination and loss of lateral strength.
The analysis revealed that the problem was due to the formation of microbubbles in the inner layer during the gluing process, caused by poor heat transfer and pressure in the corrugating roller.

Root Cause: Wear and surface irregularity on the corrugating roller, causing thermal and pressure variations during lamination, which generated bonding failures between the cardboard layers.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The material was submitted for review by the PCE resident team, with 100% inspection of the packaging to identify and separate any delaminated units.

Only compliant packaging is being released for use under temporary control.

Long Term Solution: Replacement of the worn corrugator roller responsible for the gluing failure.

Implementation of preventive maintenance and periodic calibration of the corrugator rollers to ensure proper temperature and pressure.

Training of the operations and maintenance team on process monitoring and adjustment to prevent recurrence.

description:
Where: Line T04
Description: EPS Cushion
Invoice: 000008054-7
Qty:1.596
Part number: M44GB931101E18
Defect Rate (FOR): 50/1.596 = 3,1% 31.328PPM
Rate: 3,1% 
Symptom:Wet Cushion
cause:
Analysis: The immediate cause is linked to the early delivery schedule, which concentrated the entire two-week schedule into just two days, forcing production to slam on deliveries. The reduced drying time, combined with the delay in unloading the trunk, generated condensation and water droplets on the parts immediately after unloading. The problem was not detected earlier because moisture levels were within the expected range (<5%) and there were no visible signs of surface moisture upon shipment.

Root Cause: Advance scheduling, which concentrated production and delivery in two days, eliminating the necessary margin for drying the parts and favoring condensation during transportation and unloading.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Immediate rework of the material by the KNAUF resident team.

Availability of an employee on an extra shift to support rework and minimize impact on the production line.

Long Term Solution: Conduct systematic demand, inventory, and production analysis to avoid short-term delivery congestion.

Prioritize unloading EPS trunks to prevent condensation and ensure material integrity.

description:
Where: Line T02
Description: Rear Cover 
Invoice: 0467940-1
Qty: 1.408
Part number: M34T39540GM05K02BZ
Defect Rate (FOR): 43/1.408 = 3,1% 30.540 PPM
Rate: 3,1% 
Symptom: Warped rear cover
technicalAnalysis: 17/10/2025 - Change of  action plan implementation target - Action is in development
cause:
Analysis: The rear covers showed lateral warping caused by stacking them on the Euro pallet. The dividers used were smaller than the piece and couldn't support the weight of the second layer, causing the pieces in the first layer to warp. The problem wasn't detected during in-process inspection because the warping only manifests itself after batch formation and storage.

Root Cause: The packaging dividers could not support the weight of the second layer and were smaller than the piece, causing warping.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution:  Immediate review of the material by the PAM resident team.

Review of parts in stock.

Change in the number of parts in the Euro pallet (22 → 18 pieces).

Provide guidance to operators/inspectors regarding the detected problem.

Long Term Solution:  Updated work instructions with new part layout.

Created new dividers (435 x 700) to support the weight of the second layer and prevent contact with the lower layer.

description:
Where: Line T05
Description: Carton Box
Invoice: 000389732-1
Qty: 600
Part number: M44GF58181304C0PHX
Defect Rate (FOR): 600/600 = 100% 1.000.000 PPM
Rate: 100% 
Symptom: Rupture at the box side
technicalAnalysis: 03/11/2025 - E-mails sent to the supplier asking for the 8D analysis
cause:
Analysis: During incoming inspection, ruptures were found in the perforation area of the packaging box model 27M2N3200L.
The issue occurred because the perforation cut was too deep, weakening the structure and causing the material to tear during handling.

Root Cause: The issue occurred because the perforation cut was too deep, weakening the structure and causing the material to tear during handling.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The material was fully re-inspected and sorted by supplier representatives to separate defective units and ensure only conforming parts were used.

Long Term Solution: Implement pressure control parameters in the machine setup procedure to ensure consistent cutting conditions.

Replace high-density rubber (yellow) with medium-density rubber (blue) to improve cushioning and prevent overcutting.

Standardize and document the setup and verification process after every format change to prevent recurrence.

description:
Where: Line T02
Description: Rear Cover 
Invoice: 814695-2
Qty: 1.500
Part number: M34T39540GM05K01BZ
Defect Rate (FOR): 48/1.500 = 3,2% 32.000 PPM
Rate: 3,2% 
Symptom: Warped rear cover
cause:
Analysis: Warping of the parts was detected during the process, primarily caused by improper packaging. Stacking the boxes causes deformation, allowing for incorrect assembly during production. The problem was not detected during the initial inspection, as the damage occurred during storage and transportation.

Root Cause: Inadequate packaging, which does not guarantee the integrity and conformity of the parts during storage and handling.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Material review by supplier support (immediate action to screen and control impact on production).

Long Term Solution: Development of a new packaging option.

Change in packaging method.

Issuance of a quality alert.

Implementation of controlled batch shipping until the final solution is validated.

description:
Where: Line T02
Description: Rear Cover 
Invoice: 814951-2
Qty: 1.500
Part number: M34T39540GM05K01BZ
Defect Rate (FOR): 36/1.500 = 2.4% 24.000 PPM
Rate: 2.4% 
Symptom: Warped rear cover
cause:
Analysis: It was discovered that parts of different versions were mixed within the same batch. The problem occurred due to a failure to change versions during the production process, where the previous labels were not recalled and there were no formal setup instructions. Furthermore, the control plan did not include label version verification, allowing the error to go undetected.

Root Cause: Ausência de instrução de Set up formalizada e ausência de controle específico para versão de produto (etiquetas), o que levou à mistura de peças diferentes dentro do mesmo lote.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Material review by supplier support to correctly segregate and identify parts.

Long Term Solution: Preparation of setup instructions for product version changes.

Operator training on QSB regarding setup instructions.

Inclusion of the version label verification step in the product's instruction

Operator and inspector training regarding the version issue.

Preparation and dissemination of a Quality Alert to prevent recurrence.

description:
Where: Line T03
Description: Carton Box
Invoice: 000391071-1
Qty: 1.329
Part number: M44GND4381303B
Defect Rate (FOR): 12/1.320 = 0,9% 9.091 PPM
Rate: 0,9% 
Symptom: Glue Insufficiency on the closing joints
symptom: Glue Insufficiency on the closing joints
cause:
Analysis: It was identified that the glue was being applied incorrectly.
The analysis revealed that the application sensor received an incorrect position signal, caused by an intermittent electronic failure in the encoder, which controls the exact point of glue application.
The defect was intermittent and difficult to detect, as the equipment appeared to be operating normally and the problem did not occur continuously, thus escaping random inspection.

Root Cause: The root cause was an intermittent electronic failure in the encoder, which sent incorrect position information to the application sensor, causing the glue in the boxes to misalign.
The failure was likely caused by component instability, caused by mechanical shock or electronic wear.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Supplier support reviewed and reworked the affected material.

Full batch inspection (100%) to ensure no substandard boxes were released.

Intensive monitoring of the glue application process until the defective component was replaced.

Long Term Solution: Replacement of the defective encoder with a new component.

Recalibration of the adhesive application system, adjusting positioning and signal reading.

Functional validation of the new equipment through in-line simulation.

Updating the preventive maintenance plan, including periodic inspections and testing of encoders and sensors to prevent recurrence.

description:
Where: Line T03
Description: Remote Control
Invoice: 0014425-6
Qty: 7.200
Part number: 398GR08BELGN0800WX
Defect Rate (FOR): 1/84 = 1,2% 11.905 PPM
Rate: 1,2%
Symptom: Remote Control does not works
cause:
Analysis: During OBA inspection, one remote control failed to operate. Functional testing confirmed that the LED emitter was mounted with inverted polarity, which prevented the remote from transmitting the infrared signal.

Root Cause: The LED was preformed manually with inverted polarity due to the absence of an automatic preforming/cutting machine.
Additionally, the functional test software was corrupted after a PC restart, which prevented detection of the issue during production.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Retesting of 6,233 remote controls performed at Envision to ensure correct LED functionality.

Internal stock review conducted (cut-off lot CQ-0079).

Joint defect analysis completed between Envision and UEI engineering/quality teams.


Long Term Solution: Develop and implement a visual inspection device using an LED indicator to verify correct polarity before assembly.

Update engineering instruction ENG-ITP-227 to include the new LED preforming and inspection method.

Train all involved personnel on the updated LED preforming and inspection procedure.

description:
Where: IQC
Description: EPS Cushion
Invoice: 000010775-7
Qty: 1.200
Part number: M44G5000GF1ZT02001 /M44G5000GF1ZB02001/ M44G5000GF1LR02001
Defect Rate (FOR): 32/1.200 = 2.7% 26.667 PPM
Rate: 2,7%
Symptom: Wet cushion
technicalAnalysis: 01/12/2025 - E-mail to the sdupplier asking for the action plan evidences
cause:
Analysis: During transport, the truck body was struck by branches while maneuvering in heavy rain and wind. This impact damaged the roof of the truck body, creating leaks that wet part of the EPS insulation. There was no leakage during loading, therefore the problem occurred during transit, making prior detection by the driver impossible due to adverse weather conditions.

Root Cause: Damage to the cargo compartment roof caused by impact with tree branches during maneuvering in stormy conditions, resulting in leaks that soaked the transported material.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Rework of wet EPS shims performed by KNAUF residents, ensuring that only compliant parts were used.

Long Term Solution: Repair (fiberglass reinforcement) of the damaged cargo box roof.

Preventive inspection for possible leaks in other cargo boxes.

Tree trimming near the maneuvering route to prevent further impacts.

description:
Where: Line T02
Description: Back Cover
Invoice: 0473962-1
Qty: 2.176
Part number:M34T40470GM03K01BZ 
Defect Rate (FOR): 21/840 = 2,5% 25.000 PPM
Rate: 2,5%
Symptom: Back cover broken
cause:
Analysis: The side claw of the rear cover showed warping/breakage due to the presence of plastic material trapped in the mold cavity, combined with insufficient polishing in the claw area. This condition resulted in a molding failure. The problem was not identified during inspection because this area was not a checkpoint in the work instructions or the inspection report.

Root Cause: Plastic material trapped in the mold cavity and insufficient polishing in the gripper area, resulting in deformation during the injection process.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Perform a 100% review of the rear covers in the process, with a specific focus on the side gripper for segregation of non-conforming parts.

Long Term Solution: Removal of material stuck in the mold cavity and proper polishing.

Update of work instruction to include side grip verification.

Update of inspection report to include this control point.

Issuance of quality alert to guide the team on the failure mode and prevention.

description:
Where: Line T02
Description: EPS CUSHION
Invoice: 000011275-7
Qty: 32
Part number:M44GJD12101000 / M44GJD12201000
Defect Rate (FOR): 32/792 = 4,0% 40.404 PPM
Rate: 4,0%
Symptom: Wet cushion
cause:
Analysis: The problem occurred because EPS blocks were shipped wet, a result of a failure to adhere to FIFO (First In, First Out) during loading. Pieces with more recent dates were selected while older, already stabilized material was available. The team did not properly verify the production date at the time of shipment, and the surface moisture was not identified by the loading inspection.

Root Cause: The root cause is the failure to adhere to FIFO (First In, First Out) in the logistics process, resulting in the shipment of more recently produced materials, still susceptible to moisture, while older, properly stabilized material was in stock.
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: The immediate solution adopted was containment through drying of the EPS blocks, carried out by KNAUF residents, ensuring that the affected material could be recovered or evaluated before use.

Long Term Solution: Organize shipments strictly following FIFO (First In, First Out), ensuring that older materials are used first.

Guide and train the logistics team on the correct procedure described in IPC-01.7 – Finished Product Storage, reinforcing date control and loading verification.

description:
Where: Line T01
Description: Back Cover
Invoice: 0842991-2
Qty: 87
Part number: M34T39530GM06K01BZ
Defect Rate (FOR): 87/1130 = 7,7% 76.991 PPM
Rate:7,7%
Symptom: Warped Back Cover
cause:
Analysis: Warping (dimensional deformation) was identified in the back covers after storage and transport processes. The analysis demonstrated that the production process (injection molding) operated within approved parameters, ruling out machine and process issues as the cause. The problem is associated with the packaging used, which did not offer adequate geometric support for the part, combined with stacking, storage time, and environmental variations. Furthermore, there were no specific tests or inspections to assess post-transport deformations, preventing early detection of the nonconformity.

Root Cause: Systemic failure in the packaging definition, validation, and control process, due to non-compliance with the TUTIPLAST internal procedure (APQP – items 11.1 and 11.2), resulting in the use of non-validated packaging for storage and transport, which caused the warping of the back cover
correctiveActions:
Short Term Solution: Review and screening of existing material by supplier support, blocking non-conforming parts and releasing only approved parts, ensuring immediate service without additional impact on the customer.

Long Term Solution: Redesign and development of new packaging with adequate support for the part's geometry, fully complying with APQP, including stacking, transport and storage tests, formal validation via FAPE-TUTIPLAST-8.3-01, definition of a cut-off point between packages and updating of technical documentation to prevent recurrence.
